instruction: Question: Is this a design lab issue or a common problem when using exocad?
output:
Response from Smart Mouth Technologies:

The issue is likely due to tight screw access channels caused by printer variability.

instruction:
Radiused clamping surface distributes load evenly around shaft and head
Vertical clamping priority reduces lateral stress
Smaller screw head (enabled by shaft-based retention) preserves prosthetic material and increases prosthetic strength

Purchasing Options



Quantity,	Price	,	Discount,	Bonus Tokens (Value),	Total Value
10,		$180,—,—,—
50,		"$1,140",	5% off,		10 tokens ($132.50),	$72.50 + $60
100,		"$2,160",	10% off,	10 tokens ($312.50),$72.50 + $240
Bulk,Call for custom pricing,,,


Technical Specifications

Head diameter: 2.00 mm
Screw-channel diameter: 2.04 mm
Clamping force: ~136 N
Screw-channel stress: ~35 MPa
Driver: 0.048″ (1.22 mm) hex
Required due to reduced head size

Angle correction: Not available at this time (rarely needed with smaller head)

Intended Use & Compatibility

Primary application: Direct-to-MUA (multi-unit abutment)
Not compatible with single-unit Ti-base restorations (incorrect thread pattern)

Design Libraries

Exocad
3Shape
Hyperdent
Millbox
Milling note: Screw channels millable with 1 mm endmill

Compatible MUA Brands
3i® • Adin® • Astra® • BlueSkyBio® • Biohorizons® • Cortex® • Dentsply® • Dess® • GenTek ZFX® • Hiossen® • Keystone® • Megagen® • Medentika IPS® • Neodent® • NobelBiocare® • Noris® • Osstem® • Southern Implants® • SRL® • Straumann® • Thommen Medical® • ZFX® • ZimVie®

Frequently Asked Questions
Q: Which screw-channel geometries are supported?
output:
A: Badger, Powerball, Dess Long (1.4 mm thread), Dess Short, Rosen
Q: Are Ti-bar cases supported?

instruction:
A: Badger, Powerball, Dess Long (1.4 mm thread), Dess Short, Rosen
Q: Are Ti-bar cases supported?
output:
A: Not at this time—software is limited to monolithic cases
Q: Is the software FDA-certified?

instruction:
A: Not at this time—software is limited to monolithic cases
Q: Is the software FDA-certified?
output:
A: No
Q: What if my arch still breaks?

instruction:
A: No
Q: What if my arch still breaks?
output:
A: WIB cannot guarantee outcomes due to variables outside design (manufacturing errors, implant positioning, installation technique, patient habits)
Q: Where are common stress points?

instruction:
A: WIB cannot guarantee outcomes due to variables outside design (manufacturing errors, implant positioning, installation technique, patient habits)
Q: Where are common stress points?
output:
A: Run the 6 simulations—typical hotspots appear on:

Cantilevers
Interproximal areas between teeth
MUA base transitions
Sharp geometric transitions

Smart Mouth Technologies - Website Summary
Company Focus: Smart Mouth Technologies combines engineering with full arch prosthetics to advance prosthetic outcomes in dentistry.

instruction:
INTRODUCTION & LEARNING OBJECTIVES
Q: What is the title of the presentation?
output:
A: The $9-$35 Part That Makes or Breaks a Full Arch Case

Q: What is the quick poll question?

instruction:
A: The $9-$35 Part That Makes or Breaks a Full Arch Case

Q: What is the quick poll question?
output:
A: “Biggest headache in the last 12 months—loosening / fractures / seating issues / none?”

Q: What are the learning objectives?

instruction:
A: “Biggest headache in the last 12 months—loosening / fractures / seating issues / none?”

Q: What are the learning objectives?
output:
A: 
- Understand Screw Mechanics and Physics of the Badger Screw
- Q&A

## 2.

instruction: WHAT PROBLEMS DOES THE BADGER SCREW SOLVE?
output: Q: What makes a good screw?

instruction: Q: What makes a good screw?
output:
A: 
- Small access hole size
- High clamping force
- Low Stress–High contact area
- Has good features yet high performance

Q: What do today’s screws focus on instead of performance?

instruction:
A: 
- Small access hole size
- High clamping force
- Low Stress–High contact area
- Has good features yet high performance

Q: What do today’s screws focus on instead of performance?
output:
A: Features (Price, Large angle correction, Height Adjustability, Color)

Q: Features ≠ Outcomes.

instruction: What should be measured instead?
output:
A: Performance metrics:
- Access hole diameter
- Preload (N)
- Bearing surface/screw seat stress
- Contact area

> "Features ≠ Outcomes" [Red] | "Measure What Matters" [Green]

## 3.

instruction:
UNDERSTANDING PRELOAD & CLAMPING FORCE
Q: What is preload or clamping force?
output: A: The ONLY component that keeps the prosthesis seated.

instruction: Q: What counteracts screw preload?
output: A: Force applied on the prosthesis.

instruction: Q: What happens if there is not enough preload?
output:
A: 
- Eventually screw is unloaded
- Prosthesis is no longer secured
- Screw can loosen and, over time, back out fully

## 4.

instruction:
CLAMPING FORCE RESULTS (Zirconia Prosthesis)
Q: How does Badger compare in clamping force?
output: A: Highest initial and settled force among tested screws.

instruction:
SCREW DESIGN PRINCIPLES
Q: Why do sharp edges matter?
output:
A: BAD – Concentrates stress

Q: What is better than sharp edges?

instruction:
A: BAD – Concentrates stress

Q: What is better than sharp edges?
output:
A: Rounded contours → dissipate stress

Q: What else affects performance?

instruction:
A: Rounded contours → dissipate stress

Q: What else affects performance?
output:
A: Material thickness under screw head

## 7.

instruction:
ZIRCONIA BEHAVIOR
Q: How does clamping force behave in PMMA/printed arches?
output:
A: Settles rapidly – can lose up to 100N of preload in seconds

Q: How does clamping force behave in zirconia?

instruction:
A: Settles rapidly – can lose up to 100N of preload in seconds

Q: How does clamping force behave in zirconia?
output:
A: Stable over time, minimal settling

> Graphs: 
> - Zirconia: Flat line ~300–350 N after initial spike
> - PMMA: Rapid drop from ~350 N → ~250 N within 100 seconds

## 8.

instruction:
CYCLIC LOADING
Q: What is the mouth in terms of mechanical stress?
output:
A: A cyclic loading machine

Q: In cyclic loading (PMMA), how does Badger perform vs popular screw?

instruction:
A: A cyclic loading machine

Q: In cyclic loading (PMMA), how does Badger perform vs popular screw?
output:
A: 
- Badger 15 Ncm: settles at ~273 N
- Badger 20 Ncm: settles at ~229 N
- Popular Screw 0.8mm 15 Ncm: settles at ~195 N
- Popular Screw 1.4mm 15 Ncm: settles at ~105 N

> Graph shows Badger maintaining highest force over 200 seconds of cyclic loading.

instruction:
TORQUE SPECIFICATION & SAFETY
Q: What factors determine torque recommendations?
output:
A: 
- Retaining clamping force as screw is angled
- Screw elongation
- Margin of safety
- Avoid approaching elastic limit (60% of elastic limit = proof)
- Higher validated torque → more preload

Q: Torque-Preload by Angle (Linear Fit Data):
| Angle | R²     | Slope (N/Ncm) |
|-------|--------|---------------|
| 0°    | 0.983  | 44.48         |
| 5°    | 0.979  |               |
| 10°   | 0.974  |               |
| 15°   | 0.989  |               |
| 20°   | 0.986  |               |

> Test: Badger Screw torqued to 35 Ncm shows no permanent deformation.

instruction: Q: What is the myth about angled screws?
output: A: The "wedge effect" is a myth!

instruction:
MILLING INSTRUCTIONS
Q: Can you mill Badger if you mill Vortex or Powerball?
output:
A: Yes

Q: Supported CAM software?

instruction:
A: Yes

Q: Supported CAM software?
output:
A: Hyperdent or Millbox (updated versions)

Q: Required tools for milling Badger SCREW?

instruction:
A: Hyperdent or Millbox (updated versions)

Q: Required tools for milling Badger SCREW?
output:
A: 
- Ball endmills
- Flat endmills
- Bullnose endmills
- T-cutters for angles (1.4 mm and 1.6 mm)

> Clarification: 
**Ball, flat, or bullnose endmills can be used to mill the Badger Screw seat and access channel.

instruction:
Color-coded 3D results instantly highlight weak zones
360° interactive viewer for detailed inspection

What is FEA?
output:
A proven engineering method that:

Divides the prosthetic into thousands of tiny triangles (nodes)
Applies real-world forces to each node
Predicts stress, strain, and failure points

Software Requirements

Platform: Any modern browser (desktop or mobile)
Token system: Purchased via website
Mobile capability: View (but not run) simulations on phones/tablets

Token Pricing & Usage

Cost per token: $7.25
Tokens per case: 10
Simulations per case: 6 (different load scenarios)

Upload Requirements
Double-Arch Cases

Designed prosthetics aligned in occlusion
Construction info exported from CAD software

Single-Arch Cases

Designed prosthetic
Opposing jaw scan aligned in occlusion
Construction info exported from CAD software

Q: Where do I access results?
